0.4: The small flower buds have a sweet, heady aroma.

1.4: The underside of each leaf is oddly sticky.

3.4: Exists in symbiosis with a colony of ants. The plant's stems are crawling with them.

4.4: The edges of its broad leaves are razor-sharp.

5.4: Transporting this species across government borders carries a hefty fine.

6.4: It doesn't trust you to water it.

7.4: The lush potted grass provides a good hiding spot for illicit items.

9.4: Packages the immense energy of lightning storms in a convenient format.

10.4: Cute bee vomit factories for your farm. The enslaved insects produce honey in all seasons but winter.

12.4: The liquid inside burbles and sloshes even when no one is near the barrel.

13.4: Turns ore and coal into metal bars. Is it big enough to fit a person inside?

15.4: Preserves food long beyond its best-by date.

16.4: Congeals microbe-riddled mammary liquids into a solidified mass.

17.4: Turns stolen sheep fur into fabric!

19.4: Squeezes the fat from organic materials to make lubricant. The mayor appreciates its work.

20.4: A dark enchantment on this machine defies the laws of entropy.

21.4: Advanced replicator technology. For better or for worse, it only works on shiny rocks.

24.4: Pulverizes unborn critters and blends them with oil to make sandwich spread.

25.4: Sucks the life from your crops so you can grow them anew.

28.4: A freshly harvested skeleton. Makes a useful tool for learning anatomy.

32.4: Stones like these are often used as burial monuments.

33.4: Purely decorative. There's no one inside... wait...

34.4: Using this as decoration only would be dangerous blasphemy.

36.4: Unusually life-like. The material seems artificial, but you can't be sure.

37.4: Use an item on this to trap its image inside. The item won't be consumed.

38.4: Use an item on this to trap its image inside. The item won't be consumed.

40.4: Full-grown. This species takes two winters to become sexually mature.

44.4: Viciously attacks when it thinks its young canes are threatened.

46.4: Count the rings to learn how old this tree had grown before being killed.

47.4: It's best not to ask where this came from...

48.4: It changes form every season, but you're not sure how.

52.4: Medusa got to the poor critter.

53.4: Medusa got to the poor critter.

54.4: Medusa got to the poor critter.

55.4: Medusa got to the poor critter.

56.4: Pity the poor slime who had this growth removed.

62.4: Grows crops from any season when indoors. The dirt is full of worms and insects.

71.4: Hopefully the monsters chasing you won't know how to use stairs.

83.4: Dark arts practitioners know better than to linger near its cursed aura.

85.4: Gunther said it was a sloth, but you're not so sure...

86.4: When you look closely, the bones don't all seem to match.

87.4: Ugh, the pelvic bone looks oddly human.

88.4: The inside is covered in jagged crystals, with a hollow space large enough to enclose a small child.

89.4: If you put your whole arm inside, you might be able to reach the bottom.

90.4: Thin cracks suggest it's been shattered once before. You're not sure how safe this is.

94.4: Emits a captivating melody. The longer you listen, the harder it is to move away.

95.4: No matter where you go, you can feel a pair of eyes watching your every movement.

98.4: Wh... where did the thing go that was inside it?

104.4: Should be serviced regularly to avoid risk of sudden fire or explosions.

105.4: Handy tools to drain the life out of trees!

108.4: The flowers are so fragrant, they mask all other odors.

109.4: The flowers are so fragrant, they mask all other odors.

110.4: An unfortunate prince cursed into stasis. Collect them all! (1 of 8)

112.4: Plenty of sun, not enough water.

113.4: A miserable sorceress cursed into stasis. Collect them all! (2 of 8)

114.4: Burns once-living things into lumps of useful coal.

116.4: A shiny prop for your meager self-esteem.

117.4: Just enough to keep you coming back.

126.4: An ethereal being cursed into stasis. Collect them all! (3 of 8)

127.4: It seems to know the preferences of everyone in town...

130.4: Out of sight, out of mind.

136.4: A living sculpture cursed into stasis. Collect them all! (4 of 8)

137.4: A hapless farmer cursed into stasis. Collect them all! (5 of 8)

138.4: A live dwarf child cursed into stasis. Collect them all! (6 of 8)

139.4: An unlucky scavenger cursed into stasis. Collect them all! (7 of 8)

140.4: A possessed mask cursed into stasis. Collect them all! (8 of 8)

141.4: PARENTAL ADVISORY: may cause fits of frustration-induced violence.

143.4: Fends off the terrors of the night. Provides moderate light.

144.4: Suitable for burnt offerings. Provides moderate light.

145.4: A testament to your vanity. Provides moderate light.

147.4: Only you can prevent forest fires. Provides moderate light.

148.4: A wooden masterpiece to burn. Provides moderate light.

149.4: No, this isn't a real skull... probably. Provides moderate light.

150.4: A fire in a wooden barrel sounds very safe. Provides moderate light.

151.4: Burn things in style. Provides moderate light.

152.4: An industrial age tool correlated with reduced homicide rates. Provides abundant light.

153.4: An industrial age tool correlated with reduced homicide rates. Provides abundant light.

154.4: Produces bait. Close the lid to give the worms some privacy.

156.4: Brings writhing, oozing creatures to life. Place slime eggs inside to hatch them.

158.4: Compresses slaughtered slime remains into a new life form.

159.4: The reward for thy suffering is more suffering.

160.4: Beware the curse. Too much iridium.

163.4: Stuff it with fermented fruits or congealed milk products to ripen them with age. Use in the cellar.

164.4: This statue would look good in purple shorts.

165.4: You've never seen it move, yet it somehow collects everything each morning...

167.4: An aggregation of trapped souls, hostile enough to drive thieving creatures away from a distance (about 16 "tiles").

188.4: Dies and grows back every year, but it never seems to need water.

192.4: This artificial plant somehow changes with the seasons.

196.4: It's happiest in the hot sun of the desert.

200.4: An invasive species, this shrub causes colony collapse disorder in local bee populations.

208.4: It's well taken care of, but you can never clean the blood out from the cracks in the wood.

209.4: Supposedly battery-powered, but the power source never seems to need replacement.

211.4: Breaks things down into tiny pieces. Meant for hardwood, but maybe a body would fit...

216.4: Not big enough for meat. Storing crops and forage ingredients will have to do.

Silo.9: Stores dead organisms to feed your livestock.

Mill.9: Crushes things into fine powder. Be careful not to lose any fingers.

Junimo Hut.9: An inconspicuous form of magical creature slavery.

Gold Clock.9: Fundamentally alters the flow of space-time on your farm. Debris and fences become suspended in time.

Fish Pond.9: Toss your fish into a bottomless hole and hope they keep breeding down there.

504.1: Stylish, but they lack traction on muddy, slimy, or bloody surfaces.

507.1: Steel-toed to inflict hell on the shins of your enemies.

508.1: The iron mesh makes them hard to clean. Still smells of bug guts.

509.1: The fuzzy lining smells slightly of burnt meat.

510.1: Keep your feet sweaty enough to be at risk of freezing even with the insulation.

511.1: Matte black leather boots that squish and scream as you walk.

512.1: Yeah, "fire" boots. They're covered in monster blood.

513.1: Nothing happens when they are rubbed.

804.1: Emily made these to be 100% compostable! They might be composting a little already...

806.1: A little tight on the toes.

6.2: Scratchy down there, but has great airflow!

15.2: The mayor's used silk shorts. They look better on you than on Marnie's floor.

1003.2: Sewn out of warm, leathery, breathable bat wings.

1004.2: The decal on the front sports shaved-off bits of actual bone.

1017.2: For holding up your lucky shorts.

1030.2: Complete with "secret stash" in the pocket.

1034.2: A hand-me-down adventurer's tunic. Tragically, it's not puncture-resistant.

1138.2: Looks badass as hell, but you'll smell like a brewery.

1185.2: The buttons are peculiar red stones. Wearing it brings an ever-present aura of low-level dread.

1190.2: It smiles so you don't have to.

1210.2: A couple spiders shake loose when you pick it up.

1217.2: It smells strongly of sour milk.

1220.2: A shirt with a metal chain sewn around the neck.

1224.2: Fabric laced with diamond dust. Not very comfortable to wear.

1225.2: AAH! GET IT OFF! GET IT OFF!!!

1236.2: The red stuff is probably spaghetti sauce. Or plausibly, anyway.

1239.2: Remember: you go down with your ship.

1244.2: The hieroglyphic warning probably wasn't important.

1246.2: Wear egg on your face AND on your torso.

1247.2: Well aren't you a tasty snack!

1257.2: Features the iconic spring mushroom in all its holey goodness.

1258.2: Causes your eyes to water. Or is that just seasonal allergies?

1275.2: Dust thou art, and to dust thou shalt return...

1289.2: A stylish getup for a funeral or an ex-lover's wedding.

0.1: There's a small, round hole torn out of the brim.

2.1: A bit ostentatious for funerals, but you do you.

6.1: Provides top-notch impairment of your peripheral vision.

9.1: The ears move as your expression does, but you find no mechanism for this.

10.1: Rubbery and cold, just like chicken skin.

11.1: They won't block out the voices in your head...

14.1: Flutters frantically in only a sight breeze.

19.1: M'lady, may I take your chair, bitch?

24.1: It feels damp against your eyelid when you wear it. Smells odd.

25.1: Lure children in with promises of presents.

27.1: A funny dent has caved it in on one side. It's otherwise in great condition!

29.1: The flower's lifeblood fades in vain while trying to beautify your face.

30.1: The rind drips juices into your hair.

31.1: Me gonna be deaf now, poke.

40.1: It slowly absorbs life energy from your scalp, waiting for the day you die.

41.1: 100% organic. Emily made it with her love... I don't want to know from what.

42.1: Warn others of your toxic personality.

46.1: A stylish excuse for cultural appropriation.

67.1: Sharp spines pierce your face whenever you put it on. It's uncomfortable.

71.1: It may be practical, but your style choices are hideous.

16.5: A hotly pungent, fleshy root. Crushing or grinding it releases the flavor and heat.

18.5: Contains a sap poisonous to many other plants and animals. Gifting a single flower is considered bad luck.

20.5: Some wild animal marked its territory on this one.

22.5: The leaves are a powerful diuretic; eating them increases urine production.

24.5: It has all the flavor of a bleached, long-dead carrot.

60.5: This gem is thought to guard against memory loss. A thoughtful gift for divorcees.

62.5: Thought to protect against seasickness and tragic sailing accidents.

64.5: The "pigeon's blood" variety of this gem is its most sought-after color variant.

66.5: Some sources suggest that this stone is used to stabilize mental disorders.

68.5: When worn as a necklace, this gemstone is believed to drive away sadness.

70.5: In many cultures, this stone has a strong association with the dead.

71.5: The mayor's used silk shorts. They look better on you than on Marnie's floor.

72.5: This one seems to be clear of blood.

74.5: You can feel the colour vibrate in your skull. Looking at it too long might alter your vision permanently.

79.5: Better hope it's not about you...

82.5: The red glow of this crystal never seems to fade.

84.5: The last remnant of some long forgotten creature.

86.5: A cloudy, fragile gemstone commonly gifted by cheapskates.

88.5: Covered in rough hair, it provides both milk and meat.

96.5: A scroll written in an ancient language... it probably isn't calling for genocide of surface dwellers, right?

97.5: A scroll written in an ancient language, describing a species that never expected to become endangered.

98.5: A scroll written in an ancient language, the writer unaware their days were numbered.

99.5: A scroll written in an ancient language. It seems to end abruptly...

100.5: Hopefully not used in any sacrificial rituals.

101.5: Even early tools were designed to kill.

104.5: Legend says they are enchanted to be as warm as their owners. It's cold to the touch.

107.5: Perhaps it can still hatch... what could go wrong?

111.5: A modern tool of animal abuse.

112.5: It reminds you of your old manager.

115.5: May have been used for primitive eviscerations.

117.5: This wasn't meant to be lost.

120.5: Despite its age, the rock's edge is still deadly sharp.

126.5: What a beautiful smile you have.

127.5: It just wants to spend your whole life with you.

148.5: Wriggles and writhes just like some long organ.

150.5: Its fertilized eggs float on the surface and hatch within a day, serving as food for other prey.

402.5: The flower's wiry tendrils cling possessively to its surroundings.

403.5: Flosses your teeth and gums as you eat it. Moderate to severe bleeding is normal.

404.5: Someday they will decompose *your* remains. If you must eat, chew gently.

405.5: Decorate with milled tree carcasses. Place on the ground to create paths or floors.

406.5: Watery and tasteless. The weak flavor is overpowered by the fruit's pungent smell.

407.5: Small, sharp rocks to step on. Place on the ground to create paths or floors.

408.5: Oddly large. Its unnatural growth may be caused by Joja-brand pesticides.

409.5: Falling on this surface risks a thousand cuts. Place on the ground to create paths or floors.

410.5: One legend claims that they darken in color as the devil himself enters the fruit.

411.5: Naturally rounded into a good throwing size. Place on the ground to create paths or floors.

412.5: Do you assume every dirty lump you dig up is edible?

413.5: You can see the embryo of a baby slime bouncing within. Hatch it in a slime incubator.

415.5: Step on these stones like you step on others to achieve your goals. Place on the ground to create paths or floors.

416.5: Lurks out of sight under the winter snow... waiting...

417.5: An unearthly sweetness permeating this stone-fleshed berry renders it entirely inedible.

418.5: This delicate flower prefers all other flowers to be dead when it blooms in the snow.

419.5: Given time, it can dissolve submerged human teeth to nothing.

420.5: Maybe it can be made non-poisonous by parboiling... but maybe not.

421.5: Their roots easily soak up uranium, lead, and arsenic from the soil.

422.5: Brightly colored. They say this one isn't poisonous, so it should be safe to eat.

424.5: Cow milk exposed to bacteria and allowed to curdle. Eat up!

426.5: Squishy, congealed milk from a goat's udder. Considered a delicacy by many.

428.5: An essential material for proper mummification.

430.5: Pigs find them easily due to their chemical similarities with pig mating pheromones.

433.5: Whatever you do, don't stuff it up your nose. Grows in spring and summer, reharvestable.

436.5: If cow lactations aren't your thing, try this variant!

437.5: It only takes 100 slime carcasses to make one of these. Hatch it in a slime incubator.

438.5: The goat's swollen udder must feel much better after squeezing all of this out.

439.5: A developing youngling of the most dangerous variety of slime monster. Hatch it in a slime incubator.

440.5: That sheep will be cold and shivering, but sure, enjoy how soft this is!

441.5: Owing to improper storage, it causes hundreds of unfortunate child deaths each year.

444.5: This exquisite feather was plucked out of a duck's butt.

446.5: A successful amputation from a peculiar rabbit species that seems to regrow lost feet.

447.5: Aged fish fetuses covered in a thick, gooey substance. The salt brings out the flavor.

454.5: There's no evidence to confirm whether this fruit harbors an ancient, long-dormant disease.

456.5: It's a "little" slimy. As in, "slimy to the point where you're eating more slime than soup".

457.5: Very similar to algae soup with the additional flavor of rotten eggs.

458.5: A colorful bunch of severed plant reproductive organs. Maybe your sweetheart will get the hint?

460.5: A ghost ripped this from a mermaid so you can woo your lover.

463.5: Beating this to a specific pattern might just awaken the wrong god.

464.5: Go ahead. Play your haunting melodies, see what happens.

465.5: You have to wonder if this would work on other things. Increases growth rate by at least 10%.

466.5: The long-term effects on edible produce are untested. Increases growth rate by at least 25%.

472.5: An inexpensive, fast-growing trap for beginner farmers. Plant in spring, 4 days.

473.5: It doesn't *feel* magical, but you never know. Plant in spring, 10 days, reharvestable. Trellis crop.

474.5: The crop it grows is ghostly pale. Plant in spring, 12 days.

475.5: The package says "seeds", but these are clearly potato eyes. Plant in spring, 6 days. Chance for multiple harvest.

476.5: Plant quickly, before the vampires destroy them. Plant in spring, 4 days.

477.5: They probably taste better now than when grown. Plant in spring, 6 days. Harvest with scythe.

478.5: They're pretty much weeds. Plant in spring, 13 days.

479.5: No fun in your lungs. Plant in summer, 12 days.

480.5: Sometimes they take root inside ripe tomatoes. Plant in summer, 11 days, reharvestable.

481.5: The richest source of wild seeds is fresh bear scat. Plant in summer, 13 days, reharvestable.

482.5: Not actually the hottest part of the pepper. Plant in summer, 5 days, reharvestable.

483.5: Gluten-rich. Plant in summer or fall, 4 days. Harvest with scythe.

484.5: The pod-growing seeds are sometimes pickled as a snack. Plant in summer, 6 days.

485.5: Produces a swollen, purple head. Plant in summer, 9 days.

486.5: They'll break the bank. Plant in summer, 13 days.

487.5: Terrible as popcorn. Plant in summer or fall, 14 days, reharvestable.

488.5: Flat, round eggplant spunk. Plant in fall, 5 days, reharvestable.

489.5: A plump variety of thistle. Plant in fall, 8 days.

490.5: Fished out from slimy pumpkin entrails. Plant in fall, 13 days.

491.5: Yields a cluster of erect, spoon-shaped stems. Plant in fall, 4 days.

492.5: Small slips grown by sucking nutrients from an existing yam. Plant in fall, 10 days.

493.5: Rub them into your skin to exfoliate. Plant in fall, 7 days, reharvestable.

494.5: Spiny little kernels that look like small bones. Plant in fall, 6 days.

495.5: Infested with aphids. Plant in spring.

496.5: Infested with ants. Plant in summer.

497.5: Infested with tiny beetles. Plant in fall.

498.5: Smells of stink bug. Plant in winter.

499.5: There are no library records of this ancient species, and they might not be safe for your farm. Plant anyway?

427.5: Probably overpriced. Grows in spring, 6 days. Assorted colors.

429.5: Plant these to lure and trap butterflies. Grows in spring, 7 days. Assorted blues.

453.5: Gets stuck between your teeth. Grows in summer, 7 days. Assorted colors.

455.5: Produces a highly acidic soil that kills other plants. Grows in summer, 8 days. Assorted colors.

431.5: Unsalted. Grows in summer and fall, 8 days.

425.5: Planted by sadistic fairy hunters. Grows in fall, 12 days. Assorted colors.

516.5: You wonder where the light comes from. Could this ring be radioactive?

517.5: Emits a strong, constant light. Wearing it makes your head feel funny...

518.5: Makes you a little more alluring to the objects in your surroundings.

519.5: Everything is fiercely attracted to you. You're just that irresistible.

520.5: You won't feel a thing from the slimes' touch. ;)

521.5: The sharp edges cut into your flesh, making this ring difficult to remove. But it makes you feel stronger...

522.5: It can steal the life-force of any being; hopefully not your own.

523.5: Wearing this ring overwhelms you with a sudden blood-lust.

524.5: Lets Yoba watch over you as you fight. Maybe just a little too closely...

525.5: Hardens your skin with repeated use. Negative status effects wear off sooner.

526.5: Improves your skills of thievery from corpses.

527.5: Just as uncomfortable as it looks.

529.5: Push everything and everyone further away from you.

530.5: Gleams yellow when worn; an unseen force adjusts the movements of your hand.

531.5: Sharpens your foresight and your deadly strikes.

533.5: Kill things faster than ever before.

534.5: The glowing red jewel provokes surges of indiscriminate anger.

535.5: Ask a blacksmith to shatter this poor rock, then toss it aside for the treasure within.

536.5: Ask a blacksmith to shatter this poor rock, then toss it aside for the treasure within.

537.5: Ask a blacksmith to shatter this poor rock, then toss it aside for the treasure within.

538.5: The pale glow from this crystal is a strange shade of bile green.

539.5: The mysteriously regular cubic structure seems artificially formed by someone... or something.

540.5: The semicircular "petals" of this crystal resemble a blossoming fungal growth.

541.5: A rare, sky-blue crystal that was sometimes crushed and destroyed to use in paint.

542.5: The soft crystal has been partially dissolved by weak acids.

543.5: Can sometimes form as bladder stones inside live animals. The mechanism for this is unknown.

544.5: The crystals glow bright green when stimulated. Stimulated how?

545.5: Small amounts are found in human teeth. Tiny crystals... growing... in your mouth bones...

546.5: These twinned crystals have perfect cleavage.

547.5: A rare silicate with pyroelectric properties.

548.5: A spiky, sinister-looking green crystal. It might be from another planet?

549.5: Thousands of tiny microcrystals, each one unique and entirely forgettable.

550.5: Swells up to twice its original size when heated.

551.5: They say the posessor of such a stone can command werewolves.

552.5: Toxic and water-soluable. Please do not insert it into any orifices.

553.5: Reflected in its jet-black surface you can see your face... and another face behind you.

554.5: Dwarves are said to use the powdered crystal both medicinally and recreationally.

555.5: OwO what's this? The shards are too sharp to cuddle-wuddle?

556.5: An attractive variety of arsenic mineral. Used in folk medicine, but highly toxic.

557.5: This slime has seen some things. It's best we leave it this way.

558.5: Mayonnaise from this would be crunchy.

559.5: Did you think this was gold? Sucker!

560.5: Toxin-absorbing crystals that form in the ocean near waste pipes. They emit a foul odor.

561.5: You hear strange moans in the distance when holding this crystal.

562.5: Some poor tiger was blinded for this...

563.5: It looks like it's been shattered and then reassembled. You can still see the cracks.

564.5: It looks like two other stones were fused to make this...

565.5: Many of these stones were plundered from indigenous inhabitants of the Fern Islands.

566.5: This fragile, pale crystal flares a vivid red when burned.

567.5: Some can see angels forever trapped within the stone.

568.5: Can be used to make grindstone wheels for sharpening tools or knives.

569.5: Contains traces of uranium that produce carcinogenic radon gas.

570.5: Fiber made from this rock is much safer than asbestos.

571.5: Heat it at high temperatures to produce a compound helpful for disposing of human remains.

572.5: This stone can be easily carved into all sorts of tempting shapes.

573.5: Legends claim that deposits of this ore will form wherever blood is spilled.

574.5: Porous, dull, soft and fragile. If rocks were people, it wouldn't be worthy to live.

575.5: Can be crafted into thin blades much sharper than glass. Useful for surgeries.

576.5: A material equally suited to table settings and tombstones.

578.5: A perfectly uniform structure: proof that Yoba exists... and does not care about you.

579.5: The hollow indentation could be used to hold liquid. Or soup.

581.5: The back of the skull shows a misshapen crater created by some unnatural force.

582.5: The age of these bones is about one thous... Oh! ...Oh no. They're much more recent.

583.5: Numerous fracture lines suggest that this creature suffered through frequent blunt-force trauma.

584.5: There's more backbone here than in your whole body.

586.5: Better to collect fossils than the actual creature. They're almost extinct.

587.5: Formed eons ago when a small creature fell into a mud pit and was swallowed alive by the dirt.

588.5: The spread of the five leaves resembles a human hand.

589.5: A rare fossil that includes all the appendages and guts, not just a sloughed-off exoskeleton.

591.5: Edible. If you really can't afford better food.

593.5: A beautiful star-shaped bloom whose stem contains a deadly poison.

595.5: The sweet scent is alluring to fairies, but one sip of its nectar will turn them to stone.

597.5: Butterflies are entranced by the dangerously sweet nectar. Once they find a flower, they may never leave.

599.5: Spits on the 4 adjacent tiles every morning.

376.5: A sweet-smelling flower thought to symbolize death. Breathing its scent is almost addictive...

604.5: Every proper holiday needs a flaming dessert.

605.5: Artichokes blended to the texture of baby food. So you don't choke.

606.5: With enough oil, even the grittiest and earthiest vegetables can become edible.

607.5: Savor the rich forest flavor of charred tree seeds.

608.5: Pureed pumpkin guts surrounded with lard-filled crust.

609.5: Watch out for little worms that also like to eat crisp radishes.

610.5: A splendid mÃ©lange of textures from mushy blueberries, fuzzy apricots, and underripe melon.

611.5: Blackberries very often harbor small worms inside them. They're not harmful though, and you won't even notice them when cooked!

612.5: There's more sugar in this obesity-linked beverage than in soda.

613.5: How many worms are in this one?

614.5: A highly diluted mixture of shrub and water. Yum!

618.5: Tomatoes for people who hate tomatoes.

621.5: Dribbles on the 8 adjacent tiles every morning.

645.5: Slobbers on the 24 adjacent tiles every morning.

648.5: It's very "healthy". Tastes like eating sliced up cardboard with mayonnaise.

649.5: A garlicky slurry of rice porridge served with tasteless greens.

651.5: It has a soothing effect, just like opium.

628.5: The dismembered limb of a cherry tree, taken root. Matures in 28 days, bears fruit in spring. Only grows if the 8 surrounding "tiles" are empty.

629.5: The sliced-off arm of an apricot tree, taken root. Matures in 28 days, bears fruit in spring. Only grows if the 8 surrounding "tiles" are empty.

630.5: The mutilated limb of an orange tree, taken root. Matures in 28 days, bears fruit in summer. Only grows if the 8 surrounding "tiles" are empty.

631.5: The amputated arm of a peach tree, taken root. Matures in 28 days, bears fruit in summer. Only grows if the 8 surrounding "tiles" are empty.

632.5: The severed limb of a pomegranate tree, taken root. Matures in 28 days, bears fruit in fall. Only grows if the 8 surrounding "tiles" are empty.

633.5: The butchered arm of an apple tree, taken root. Matures in 28 days, bears fruit in fall. Only grows if the 8 surrounding "tiles" are empty.

634.5: Take care not to choke on the cyanide-filled pit.

635.5: A delicious treat for the shower.

636.5: Fuzzy to the touch with soft, sweet flesh underneath.

637.5: A known aphrodisiac with an inside texture like tiny, crunchy eyeballs.

638.5: A popular modder known for creating Train Station mod and Shop Tile Framework.

680.5: It squirms within your grasp, the embryo eagerly awaiting release. Hatch it in a slime incubator.

681.5: Activate it to play god and wreck havoc on natural weather patterns. Consumed on use.

682.5: How toxic must the town's wastewater be to have created this monstrosity?

684.5: Throw this on the grill for a late night treat!

685.5: Large bugs, slain and minced to lure in more critters for food.

686.5: Oh gosh, it's naked. Slightly increases the bite-rate when fishing.

687.5: A spinner with a sense of propriety. Increases the bite-rate when fishing.

688.5: Warps all time and space to re-center the farm on your current physical location. Consumed on use.

689.5: Warps all time and space to re-center the mountains on your current physical location. Consumed on use.

690.5: Warps all time and space to re-center the beach on your current physical location. Consumed on use.

691.5: Stab the fish when they bite the hook, stab them again when they try to wriggle free.

692.5: Wears away to nothing in 20 uses. Good job on adding to water contamination, you.

693.5: Reduces squirming hooked fish to mere side-quests on your mad hunt for treasure.

694.5: Helps thwart a hooked fish's efforts to free itself.

695.5: A nifty gimmick to fake the effect of a higher fishing level. Increases the size of your "fishing bar".

698.5: Slow-breeding bottom-feeder close to extinction. Now there's one less in the wild, courtesy of you.

699.5: Doomed to be the last of their bloodline, these unnatural hybrids can never reproduce.

700.5: In a pinch, they will even eat sewage. Beware their teeth and the poisonous barbs on their fins.

701.5: Swims with a mouth full of half-hatched babies for a week before spitting them out.

702.5: This freshwater fish is at half-mast.

703.5: Litter the rivers and ocean floor with these in search of treasure.

705.5: This "chicken of the sea" sports a ghastly visage with beak-like snout and large, glassy eyes.

706.5: Roe-filled females are especially prized; the unborn eggs are considered a delicacy.

707.5: A voracious predator that will eagerly cannibalize other lingcod of similar size.

708.5: Born with an eye on each side of its head, one eye slowly migrates across as it grows.

709.5: A formidable length of hardened wood. Very pleasing to the touch.

710.5: Place in the water and load with tantalizing insect bits. Return next day for a stinky surprise!

715.5: Raising them in captivity is difficult; their cannibalistic behaviour limits profits.

716.5: Their sperm are amoeba-shaped and crawl towards the eggs.

717.5: A sea spider, ready to be boiled alive and eaten fresh.

718.5: The cockle's large siphon pokes out from its shell, squirming like a giant tongue.

719.5: Predator snails will bore a hole through the mussel's shell and suck out its soft parts.

720.5: The largest specimen ever found was long enough to wrap around a human neck.

721.5: Seasoning with enough salt will kill it, if it's not already dead.

722.5: A squelching, slimy critter. It smells way too strong for its size.

723.5: A slimy-feeling shell means this creature is still alive.

724.5: The sweet life-blood of maple trees, extracted for consumption.

725.5: The innards of an oak tree, extracted and processed for use.

727.5: Just hot ocean milk with dead animal croutons.

730.5: Some say you can hear the lobster scream as it is boiled alive. Others say it is just the sound of steam escaping.

728.5: Avoid wasting fish scraps, heads and eyeballs by hiding them in this savory dish.

729.5: It may have a fancy French name, but it's still just snails.

731.5: A sweet treat for humans and insects alike.

732.5: Glutenous, oil-fried discs of dead crab flesh.

734.5: Lurks among the rotten wood of deep ponds.

745.5: Not even real berries, they're all impostors.

746.5: Vegetable craniotomy victim. Place its leering skull in a visible location as a warning to others.

747.5: Flies have laid eggs in the putrid mass. You should probably get rid of this.

748.5: Something wriggles just under the surface. You should probably get rid of this.

749.5: Ask a blacksmith to shatter this poor rock, then toss it aside for the treasure within. So many possibilities!

766.5: You're not sure which organ this gelatinous substance is from.

767.5: It's still twitching after being sliced off from the body.

768.5: A warm remnant of Yoba's power.

769.5: The chill you get from holding this seeps right to your core.

770.5: There's a little bit of everything in here! Not just seeds... there's a few dead bugs and animal droppings, too.

771.5: Better check it for animal droppings.

772.5: You'll ooze garlic from every pore, producing a pungent odor that is frightful to weaker monsters.

773.5: All magic comes with a price.

774.5: Bug corpses held together with Linus' special sauce.

775.5: Its eyes looked into your soul just before it passed out from heat and suffocation.

788.5: The axe cries out for its owner. Faintly you can hear it whisper, "Robin..."

790.5: Stained with what you *hope* is berry juice. It smells like Linus, and he smells awful.

795.5: Shadows have mutated this species beyond repair. Keep an eye out behind you, you could be next.

796.5: Slime oozes out from under every scale, leaving a stinging sensation on your skin.

797.5: A grain of sand that irritated an oyster until it spat on it again, and again, and again.

798.5: Every sucker on its writhing tentacles is adorned with sharp, serrated rings.

799.5: Its huge, tubular eyes point directly upwards. They are encased in a transparent dome of soft flesh.

800.5: A fish rapidly pulled from its deep-sea home. The changing pressures have almost turned it inside-out.

801.5: Binds your partner's soul to yours, 'til death do you part.

802.5: Grows a spiny plant with a nasty defense system. Plant indoors only, 12 days, reharvestable.

805.5: Forces unnaturally rapid tree growth, even in winter. Doesn't work on fruit trees.

808.5: Snatched from a mermaid's corpse and dipped in the ichor of shadow beings. A token of friendship.

809.5: Sit with strangers in the dark and pretend the room isn't gassed up with farts. Give one to a friend!

810.5: The enchanted shell might protect you, but it certainly didn't protect the crab.

811.5: Explodes enemy corpses. Violently. Wear it on a finger!

812.5: You can see tiny baby fish inside. Alive and wiggling. Age them in a preserves jar to bring out more flavor.

445.5: The salted, unborn offspring of an endangered fish species. A luxurious delicacy!

814.5: The inky emissions of a terrified sea creature.

815.5: An infusion of these can send you for a wild ride.

267.5: Two eyes on one side of its head and none on the other. It wasn't born that way.

265.5: Waterlogged and briny. There's no going back if you eat this.

0.1: Bestows tetanus on your enemies. And on you, if you're not careful.

1.1: Helpful when the howls you hear aren't just ordinary howls.

2.1: Saps the life force from your enemies and drives it through your veins.

3.1: This sword doesn't sit right in your hands. Something about you feels *wrong*.

4.1: You wield the power of the universe in your hands. Don't drop it.

5.1: A human leg bone, sharpened into a crude but piercing sword.

7.1: It belonged to a knight who once was honorable.

8.1: Sharp enough that deadly cuts are barely felt by its victims.

9.1: Cuts and cauterizes in one stroke.

10.1: It's strong enough to cleave through heavy armor.

11.1: It's not the size that counts, it's how you use it.

12.1: What a weak sword. You might as well scream "Kill me!" instead.

13.1: Insect guts and a decapitated head. Kill monsters with their own kind.

14.1: You'll be in for a world of trouble if Neptune ever comes back for it.

15.1: Even the trees are conspiring to bloodshed.

16.1: Melt through bones like butter with this knife!

17.1: Concealed and deadly. A weapon made for treachery.

18.1: Made by Pierre back in his prison days. Wonder how it got here?

22.1: Unusually light in your hands and on your conscience.

23.1: Tears holes in the space-time continuum if used improperly.

24.1: A crudely shaped club. The heavy end is pockmarked and matted with blood and hair.

26.1: The material is toxic when ingested.

27.1: Repurposed equipment from a children's game.

28.1: With this gavel in hand you can be judge, jury and executioner.

29.1: Swinging this too hard could have cosmic repercussions.

31.1: Stolen from the guy in the basement.

32.1: Hit the eyes and crush it! Yes! Requires ammo.

33.1: Adds extra strength to deliver a nice clear hole in the head. Requires ammo.

43.1: Stained with the blood of several mutinies.

44.1: Sever bodies from souls with panache!

45.1: A jagged, razor-sharp dagger rumoured to be used in ritual killings.

47.1: Cuts grass... and souls. Yields hay if you've built a silo.

50.1: Tears through flesh as fluidly as if it were paper.

51.1: A relic of the merfolk wars.

52.1: Forged to return the living to the dead.

53.1: From the hands of the Reaper himself!

Entries.Wand.cs.14319: This wand obliterates you at an atomic level, then uses advanced necromancy to resurrect you at your farm.
Entries.Axe.cs.14019: A perfect tool for chopping trees and stealing kneecaps.
Entries.Pickaxe.cs.14185: Swing to puncture through stones, debris, or almost anything else.
Entries.Hoe.cs.14102: Digs and tills soil. Don't waste your gold on it.
Entries.WateringCan.cs.14325: Used to water crops and revive drunkards. It can be refilled at any water source.
Entries.TrashCan_Description: Reduce, reuse, recycle... or not. Reclaims {0}% of the value from trashed items.
Entries.Pan.cs.14181: Dredge through muddy water in search of scant treasure, if you're that desperate.
Entries.MilkPail.cs.14168: Collect warm mammary excretions from your livestock.
Entries.FishingRod.cs.14042: Used to drag unsuspecting fish to their deaths. A fun and relaxing pastime.
Entries.FishingRod.cs.trainingRodDescription: Too incompetent to use a normal fishing rod, huh? Sucks to be you.
Entries.Shears.cs.14241: Strip sheep naked to steal their wool.
